body_html:
There is more discussions at #7731 .
While the problem might not be too hard for a few dimensions, I'm not sure I follow @apaszke 's analysis.
A "terrible-worst-case-runtime"-algorithm has been proposed in a similar discussion on stackoverflow.
Based on that I think one would want to check a few common cases (e.g. strides are commensurate) first and then perhaps do a full check if that doesn't give "safe" as an answer.

Given that it seems a fairly common issue, if we know what we want, I'd look into implementing it.

A "terrible-worst-case-runtime"-algorithm has been proposed in a similar discussion on stackoverflow.

body:
There is more discussions at #7731 .
While the problem might not be too hard for a few dimensions, I'm not sure I follow @apaszke 's analysis.
A ["terrible-worst-case-runtime"-algorithm has been proposed in a similar discussion on stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3551819/algorithm-for-determining-if-strided-arrays-overlap#3569909).
Based on that I think one would want to check a few common cases (e.g. strides are commensurate) first and then perhaps do a full check if that doesn't give "safe" as an answer.

Given that it seems a fairly common issue, if we know what we want, I'd look into implementing it.
